[QURAN:257] Publisher's Note on the English Translation of the Holy Qur'an
[QURAN:258] by Hazrat Maulana Sher Ali (ra)
[QURAN:259] By the sheer grace and mercy of Allah the Almighty,
[QURAN:260] under the blessed guidance and special directives of Hazrat
[QURAN:261] Mirza Masroor Ahmad, Khalifatul Masih V (aba), a soft-copy
[QURAN:262] of the Arabic text of the Holy Qur'an has been prepared using
[QURAN:263] the InDesign software, by the Nazarat Nashro Isha'at, Qadian,
[QURAN:264] according to the script of the Yassarnal Qur'an formed by
[QURAN:265] Hazrat Pir Manzur Muhammad Sahib (ra). This task has been
[QURAN:266] completed with a view to publish the translations of the Holy
[QURAN:267] Qur'an in numerous languages following the same pattern.
[QURAN:268] To begin with, the Nazarat Nashro Isha'at, Qadian has
[QURAN:269] prepared a soft-copy of the English translation of the Holy
[QURAN:270] Qur'an by Hazrat Maulavi Sher Ali Sahib (ra), along with the
[QURAN:271] original Arabic text.
[QURAN:272] Mr. Quraishi Mohammad Fazlullah Sahib had the honour
[QURAN:273] of conducting the checking and final reading of the
[QURAN:274] Arabic text, diligently comparing it with the original. Similarly,
[QURAN:275] Mr. Qureshi Naeem ul Haque performed the significant
[QURAN:276] tasks of incorporating corrections and undertaking the final
[QURAN:277] typesetting of the Arabic text. Mr. Nooruddin Noori, Mr. Ahmad
[QURAN:278] Sadiq Rather, Mr. Waseem Ahmed Azeem and Mr. Mohammad
[QURAN:279] Arif Rabbani also rendered their joint efforts in proofreading
[QURAN:280] the English text of the translation.
[QURAN:281] Mr. Ahsan Ghouri, Mr. K. Tariq Ahmad and Mr. Ataul
[QURAN:282] Mujeeb Lone also deserve our gratitude for their exceptional
[QURAN:283] cooperation and contributions in this noble endeavour.
[QURAN:284] May Allah bless this publication in every respect and
[QURAN:285] richly reward all those who helped contribute to bring this
[QURAN:286] noble work to fruition, Ameen.
[QURAN:287] Hafiz Makhdum Sharif,
[QURAN:288] Nazir Nashro Isha'at Qadian
[QURAN:289] 23rd March 2021
[QURAN:290] <I>

[QURAN:292] Foreword
[QURAN:293] In 2004 we published, under the auspices of I:-Ja<)rat Mirza
[QURAN:294] Masroor A]:imad, Khalifatul Mas1]:i V"t, the Royal Size of the Holy
[QURAN:295] Qur'an translated into English by I:Ia<)rat Maulaw1 Sher 'Ali with
[QURAN:296] the alternative translation of, and footnotes to, some of the verses
[QURAN:297] by I:Ia<)rat Mirza Tahir A]:imad, Khalifatul Mas1]:i IVrh_ It should
[QURAN:298] be noted that the original translation of I:Ia<)rat Maulaw1 Sher 'Ali
[QURAN:299] was not changed and the translation and notes by I:Ia<)rat Mirza
[QURAN:300] Tahir A]:imad, Khalffatul Mas1]:i IVrh, were both given below the
[QURAN:301] relevant pages of the text and translation with asterisks. We are
[QURAN:302] again privileged to publish this Royal Size edition in hardcover.
[QURAN:303] In this edition we have corrected the English names of the
[QURAN:304] Surahs according to the system of transliteration approved by
[QURAN:305] I:-Ja<)rat Khanfatul Mas1]:i yai_
[QURAN:306] We pray and hope that this new edition would find a large
[QURAN:307] circulation especially among those who suffer from Islamophobia
[QURAN:308] and do not hesitate to raise objections against the Word of Allah,
[QURAN:309] His Propheea and Islam.
[QURAN:310] I:Ia<)rat Mirza Ghulam A]:imad of Qadian, the Promised
[QURAN:311] Messiah and Mahdi"', addressing the entire world, says:
[QURAN:312] "Whenever Islam has been confronted with any other religion
[QURAN:313] in consequence of some new condition of the age, the sharp and
[QURAN:314] effective instrument that has immediately come to hand is the Holy
[QURAN:315] Qur'an. In the same way, whenever philosophic thought has been
[QURAN:316] given publicity in opposition to it, the Holy Qur'an has destroyed
[QURAN:317] that poisonous plant and has so humiliated it as to provide a
[QURAN:318] mirror to its students which shows up the true philosophy which is
[QURAN:319] contained in the Holy Qur'an alone and nowhere else."
[QURAN:320] (lziila-e-Auhiim, Ruhiinz Khazii'in, Vol. 3, p. 382)
[QURAN:321] (The Essence of Islam, Vol. I, p.355)
[QURAN:322] <S>
[QURAN:323] (See details of transliteration on page 'p').
[QURAN:324] "I call Allah to witness that the Holy Qur'an is a rare pearl.
[QURAN:325] Its outside is light and its inside is light and its above is light and
[QURAN:326] its below is light and there is light in every word of it. .. It has been
[QURAN:327] disclosed to me in a vision that the garden of holiness is irrigated
[QURAN:328] by the water of the Qur'an, which is a surging ocean of the water
[QURAN:329] of life. He who drinks from it, comes to life; indeed, he brings
[QURAN:330] others to life."
[QURAN:331] (A 'zna '-e-Kamiiliit-e-!sliim, Riihiinz Khazii 'in, Vol. 5, pp. 545-546)
[QURAN:332] (The Essence of Islam, Vol. I, p.356)

[QURAN:343] Foreword
[QURAN:344] The English translation of The Holy Qur'an by the late I:Ia<_lrat MaulawI
[QURAN:345] Sher 'An (may Allah be pleased with him) was first published in Holland in
[QURAN:346] 1955 and since then many editions have been published in different countries.
[QURAN:347] In 1997 Islam International Publications Ltd. issued a new edition with an
[QURAN:348] appendix containing alternative translations of some verses, or parts of verses,
[QURAN:349] as well as explanatory notes to some of them by f:Ia<_lrat Mirza Tahir A]:imad,
[QURAN:350] the fourth successor of the Promised Messiah (may Allah bless his soul with
[QURAN:351] His infinite mercy). In the present edition we have dropped the appendix and
[QURAN:352] brought the material under relevant verses marking them with starlets*. (The
[QURAN:353] alternative translations by I:Ia<_lrat Mirza Tahir A]:imad are given in bold letters.
[QURAN:354] But where he has made a deletion in the original translation, no bold letters
[QURAN:355] are used). This, we hope, will facilitate the reader to make full use of these
[QURAN:356] additions. Starlets are also used to indicate publisher's notes, however, at the
[QURAN:357] end of each such note, 'publisher' is printed in brackets. The symbols 't', ':I:'
[QURAN:358] indicate the original notes by the translator.
[QURAN:359] The present project was begun under the instructions of f:Ia<_lrat Mirza
[QURAN:360] Tahir A]:imad, the fourth successor of the Promised Messiah and Head of the
[QURAN:361] World Wide A]:imadiyya Muslim Jama'at (May Allah bless his soul with His
[QURAN:362] infinite mercy). Before f:Iu<_lur's demise, he constantly guided us and prayed for
[QURAN:363] us; and made some changes in, and additions to, his own translation. After his
[QURAN:364] demise, f:Ia<_lrat Mirza Masroor A]:imad, Khalffatul MasI]:i the Fifth, has been
[QURAN:365] guiding us and praying for us. Whenever we felt that in the appendix of the

[QURAN:389] In transliterating Arabic words we have followed the following system
[QURAN:390] adopted by the Royal Asiatic Society.
[QURAN:391] at the beginning of a word, pronounced as a, i, u preceded by a very slight
[QURAN:392] aspiration, like h in the English word 'honour'.
[QURAN:393] c.':.J th, pronounced like th in the English word 'thing'.
[QURAN:394] C ~' a guttural aspirate, stronger than h.
[QURAN:395] t kh, pronounced like the Scotch ch in 'loch'.
[QURAN:396] j dh, pronounced like the English th in 'that'.
[QURAN:397] 0"' ,y, strongly articulated s.
[QURAN:398] u-<> q, similar to the English th in 'this' .
[QURAN:399] .b t, strongly articulated palatal t.
[QURAN:400] b ?, strongly articulatedz.
[QURAN:401] t ', a strong guttural, the pronounciation of which must be learnt by the ear.
[QURAN:402] t gh, a sound approached very nearly in the r 'grasseye' in French, and in
[QURAN:403] the German r. It requires the muscles of the throat to be in the 'gargling'
[QURAN:404] position whilst pronouncing it.
[QURAN:405] ,j q, a deep guttural k sound.
[QURAN:406] ', a sort of catch in the voice.
[QURAN:407] Short vowels are represented by a for__,.,._ (like u in 'bud'); i for----;;;-(like i in
[QURAN:408] 'bid'); u for___1__ (like oo in 'wood'); the long vowels by a for- 1-orT(like a in
[QURAN:409] 'father'); zfor cS----;;;,-or-1-(likc ee in 'deep'); ai for t5 ___..._ (like i in 'site'); u
[QURAN:410] for _.,____...L_(like oo in 'root'); au for_., __,.,._(resembling ou in 'sound').
[QURAN:411] The consonants not included in the above list have the same phonetic
[QURAN:412] value as in the principal languages of Europe.
[QURAN:413] All praise belongs to Allah to Whom we bow in sincerest gratitude for
[QURAN:414] enabling us to complete this task.

[QURAN:418] Index of Symbols Denoting Pauses
[QURAN:419] __.. Compulsory Stop.
[QURAN:420] O The sign at the end of a verse. It is preferable, though not
[QURAN:421] necessary, to stop here .
[QURAN:422] .l, It is preferable, though not necessary, to stop here.
[QURAN:423] 6 Optional. To pause, or to continue.
[QURAN:424] i': It is better to pause.
[QURAN:425] IJ Necessary to continue, do not pause.
[QURAN:426] ~, Stop vocal sound for a moment, without breaking breath.
[QURAN:427] j~'-"'i> Desirable to continue, do not pause.
[QURAN:428] ~ Recommended pause.
[QURAN:429] :. :. Part of the verse in between these signs indicate that if you
[QURAN:430] pause at words preceded by the first sign you should not
[QURAN:431] pause at the second but if you do not pause at the first, pause
[QURAN:432] at the second.For example,
[QURAN:433] Dhalikal-Kitabu la raiba
[QURAN:434] fih, hudal-lil-muttaqin
[QURAN:435] t pause here)

[QURAN:4765] ,:, 6. Do not hand over the charge of property belonging to you which Allah has made for
[QURAN:4766] you as a means of support, to those who are mentally incapable of managing it properly.
[QURAN:4767] So feed them therewith and clothe them properly and speak kindly to them.
[QURAN:4768] Note: Here the society is addressed as a whole while the property in question is not national
[QURAN:4769] property but belongs to the orphans whose number grows exceedingly large during wars.
[QURAN:4770] Obviously a considerable part of national wealth will be involved in such exceptional
[QURAN:4771] circumstances. Tf a nation as a whole docs not take care of such property and leaves it entirely
[QURAN:4772] to the care of children, inexperienced and incapable of handling their wealth sensibly, this is
[QURAN:4773] bound to adversely influence the entire national economy. To resolve this problem the nation
[QURAN:4774] is addressed as a whole and made responsible for the proper care of the properly in question as
[QURAN:4775] if it belonged to them. It docs not mean, however, that such orphans will be disinherited or
[QURAN:4776] dispossessed of their individual rights permanently. The following verse and the verse 11
[QURAN:4777] make the real import of this verse abundantly clear.

[QURAN:5187] ,:,47. Note: Justice cannot be done to the real import of this part of the verse by mere
[QURAN:5188] translation because here the hypocrites are described as intentionally mispronouncing
[QURAN:5189] some commonly used phrases to give them a twist with the intention to insult the Holy
[QURAN:5190] Prophet (may peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The believers used the phrase
[QURAN:5191] sami 'nii wa afa 'nii ('& _; '4) which means we heard and we obeyed. Instead of saying
[QURAN:5192] afa'na('&) the hypocrites said 'ayainii (~) (the word used in the actual text of the verse)
[QURAN:5193] meaning thereby that we heard and disobeyed. Yet they pronounced it with a slur intending to

[QURAN:5536] ,:, 84. Note: This translation implies that the Messenger and the persons of authority among
[QURAN:5537] them were not all capable of drawing right conclusion. Only those among them who had the
[QURAN:5538] faculty of sound judgement could have discovered the reality. We propose an alternative
[QURAN:5539] translation as follows which does not leave this flaw and indicates that each among them had
[QURAN:5540] the capability of discovering the truth ifhe had contemplated and examined the report: "When
[QURAN:5541] they conceive (rumours concerning) a matter of peace or alarm they spread it about.
[QURAN:5542] Whereas if they had referred the matter to the '1essenger and those in authority among
[QURAN:5543] them surely of them those who had critically examined the matter could know the truth."
[QURAN:5544] ,:, 86. Whoso makes a righteous intercession shall have a share thereof, and whoso makes an evil
[QURAN:5545] intercession, shall have a like portion of evil consequences thereof; and Allah is Powerful over
[QURAN:5546] everything.
[QURAN:5547] ,:, 87. Note: This translation narrows down the application of the verse to only verbal expressions
[QURAN:5548] of goodwill while the admonition contained therein has much wider application. In fact, it
[QURAN:5549] covers not only verbal greetings but also intends gifts of all kinds to be responded to more
[QURAN:5550] generously or at least in the same measure.

[QURAN:6197] This Jewish claim is firmly rejected by the Holy Qur'an. Thal is why by the end of the verse,
[QURAN:6198] the conclusive declaration is that whatever may have happened they certainly failed to kill
[QURAN:6199] him. This implies that it is not the act of crucifixion which is denied. What is denied is death
[QURAN:6200] by crucifixion.
[QURAN:6201] Wa/iikin shuhhiha /ahum ( ~ 0 ~ ,): the word shuhhiha (0) in the text must be
[QURAN:6202] carefully studied. The context of the preceding text would not permit'the implied reference to
[QURAN:6203] any other than Jesus or alternatively it could refer to the incident in general. In conformity with
[QURAN:6204] the rules of grammar the implied pronoun in the word shubbiha (0) can refer to none other
[QURAN:6205] than Jesus Christ himself. This means that it was he who was obscured and made to appear to
[QURAN:6206] them similar to someone else. Hence as Jesus was hung upon the cross he hung in the likeness
[QURAN:6207] of someone else. Evidently the denial is not that of crucifixion or apparent death thereupon but
[QURAN:6208] the denial is death by crucifixion. There certainly was great confusion as lo what actually had
[QURAN:6209] happened. So the verse continues to build the scenario of the confusion and doubt. All else is
[QURAN:6210] nothing but conjecture. Thal is the final conclusion.
[QURAN:6211] If the word shubbiha refers to the incident as such, this would point to the divergent
[QURAN:6212] claims of the two disputing parties as to what had happened. Neither of the parties were certain
[QURAN:6213] of the validity of their claims. For instance the Christian belief of Jesus' death by crucifixion
[QURAN:6214] and later resurrection was not based on any tangible grounds but was merely conjectural.
[QURAN:6215] Likewise the Jewish claim of Jesus' death upon the cross was no less conjectural. Hence their
[QURAN:6216] appeal to Pilate for the possession of Jesus' body. In fact they clearly expressed their doubts
[QURAN:6217] regarding the entire episode of his so-called death and warned Pilate that in the likelihood of
[QURAN:6218] his survival he might reappear in public claiming that he had risen from the dead. (Matthew
[QURAN:6219] 27:63-64)
[QURAN:6220] Tt is to this that the last part of the verse under study refers, when it says wa
[QURAN:6221] innalladh,na (&.i}, i,,). Certainly those who differ about it (or about him as lo what actually
[QURAN:6222] befell him) were themselves in doubt.
[QURAN:6223] ,:, 159. Note: Bal rafa'ahulliihu ilaihi (~),i,', Ll; j.;): the majority of orthodox Muslims infer
[QURAN:6224] from this part of the verse that the connotation of Bal refers to the act of crucifixion i.e.,
[QURAN:6225] instead ofletting him die upon the cross, God rescued him by raising him bodily to somewhere
[QURAN:6226] in the heavens. As such he should be living somewhere in space in the same corporal form that
[QURAN:6227] he possessed prior to the attempt of his crucifixion. This interpretation raises many difficult
[QURAN:6228] questions, mainly:
[QURAN:6229] (a) If Jesus was not crucified at all, is the entire history of crucifixion emphatically
[QURAN:6230] denied and the whole episode just a fiction or delusion suffered by the Jews, the Christians and
[QURAN:6231] the Romans alike''
[QURAN:6232] (b) Where in the verse is the claim that Jesus was raised bodily lo heavens? All that is
[QURAN:6233] mentioned simply is that Allah exalted him to Himself.
[QURAN:6234] a i u I I th -=, I ~ T I kh r I dh ; I e er Q9 cf J, I ! b I ;, i; I ' f I gh f I q 3 I '

[QURAN:6243] As to the first question the orthodox build a fantastic scenario according to which the
[QURAN:6244] fact of crucifixion itself is not denied but it is claimed that the person who was crucified was
[QURAN:6245] not Jesus but someone else who was given the likeness of Jesus by some angels at the command
[QURAN:6246] of God. Hence the doubts and conjectures were about the identity of the person who was
[QURAN:6247] crucified. Evidently this explanation creates only more problems than it solves. Moreover, the
[QURAN:6248] entire tale is absolutely without foundation. No scriptural evidence or evidence based on the
[QURAN:6249] traditions of the Holy Prophet (may peace and blessings of Allah be on him) is ever presented
[QURAN:6250] to support this bizarre claim which simply adds more conjectural confusion.
[QURAN:6251] Tt is as if this explanation of the verse dawned only upon the medieval scholars while
[QURAN:6252] the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, remained himself completely unaware of it.
[QURAN:6253] As to the second question the weakness of the claim is apparent from the wording of
[QURAN:6254] the Holy Qur'iin. The word rafa 'a (;J;) means elevated. Whenever Allah elevates a person the
[QURAN:6255] elevation always refers to the status of the person, never to his body. In fact it is impossible to
[QURAN:6256] translate this verse in any way other than the said meaning i.e., the elevation of spiritual
[QURAN:6257] station.
[QURAN:6258] The verse declares that Allah elevated Jesus to Himself. Evidently no point in space
[QURAN:6259] of Heaven is mentioned lo which Allah raised him. He raised him lo Himself while He was
[QURAN:6260] present there where Jesus was. No place in Heaven or earth is empty of Allah's presence. So
[QURAN:6261] when someone is said lo be raised lo Him, a bodily movement is impossible and inconceivable.
[QURAN:6262] According to Ahmadiyya understanding of this verse, the connotation of 'on the contrary'
[QURAN:6263] refers to the Jewish claim of the accursed death of Jesus. Obviously the opposite of curse is
[QURAN:6264] nearness to God.
[QURAN:6265] ,:, 160. Note: This verse has been the subject of controversy regarding its real import. Some
[QURAN:6266] scholars believe that it refers to a remote future in relation to the time of crucifixion indicating
[QURAN:6267] that all Jews without exception will one day have faith in Jesus Christ and accept him as a true
[QURAN:6268] Prophet of God. They claim that it is also mentioned in this verse that this miracle would take
[QURAN:6269] place in the lifetime of Jesus Christ. This they infer from the words qahla mautihi (H~ µ)
[QURAN:6270] which means before his death.
[QURAN:6271] As the Jews have not yet accepted him, therefore, according to such scholars Jesus
[QURAN:6272] must be still alive.
[QURAN:6273] Another commonly held view is that the expression 'before his death' refers to every
[QURAN:6274] member of the Jewish faith of the time of Jesus Christ. In this case this would mean that every
[QURAN:6275] Jew would believe in Jesus Christ before his death-a claim which can only be verified by
[QURAN:6276] God.
[QURAN:6277] Unfortunately many problems and difficulties stand in the way of accepting these
[QURAN:6278] propositions in toto.
[QURAN:6279] We propose a completely different and new solution to the problem. The verse under
[QURAN:6280] study is translated as 'There is no one among the people of the Book but will certainly believe
[QURAN:6281] in him before his death."
[QURAN:6282] The word in italics i.e., 'one' is not literally mentioned in the verse but is only implied.
[QURAN:6283] If it were mentioned the verse would mean as follows:

[QURAN:7489] After having stated that minor matters and details have been left to man to legislate
[QURAN:7490] as he thinks proper, the verse fittingly draws attention lo the fact that such freedom and
[QURAN:7491] discretion arc not allowed in fi.mdamentals, because in fundamentals unanimity is essential
[QURAN:7492] and divergence of opinion may prove immensely harmful. The verse gives an illustration lo
[QURAN:7493] show that human intellect cannot be trusted with the making of the laws on fundamental
[QURAN:7494] matters. The Arabs used lo let loose the animals mentioned in the verse in honour of their idols.
[QURAN:7495] Besides being based on disbelief and superstition, the practice was also highly foolish. The
[QURAN:7496] animals thus let loose wrought great havoc wherever they went. The Qur'an refers to this evil
[QURAN:7497] practice as an example of man-made laws and warns Christians who question the wisdom ofa
[QURAN:7498] revealed Law to learn a lesson from the morally degrading practices to which the pagan Arabs
[QURAN:7499] had resorted because they had no revealed Law to guide them.

[QURAN:9108] ,:, 21. But Satan whispered suggestions to them so that he might reveal to them their shortcomings
[QURAN:9109] which had remained concealed in them of their shame, and said, 'Your Lord has only
[QURAN:9110] forbidden you this tree, lest you should become angels or such beings as live for ever.'
[QURAN:9111] Note: Most translators have taken the scenario too literally while there is enough evidence
[QURAN:9112] within the text to rule out a literal application. The sin referred lo is obviously related lo an
[QURAN:9113] internal faltering as indicated by the part of the verse which declares that (~1_;...:;) sauiituhumii
[QURAN:9114] (their weakness) became known to them. If it was a bodily nakedness how could they have
[QURAN:9115] remained unaware of their nakedness from the time of their birth to the time of the said
[QURAN:9116] incident?
[QURAN:9117] Tt is evident, therefore, that a literal meaning is wrongfully attributed to the Holy
[QURAN:9118] Qur'an. The word sau 'ii (1~) primarily applies to acts of shame and evil propensities. At the
[QURAN:9119] time of faltering the falterer discovers lo his horror his own hidden weaknesses. This weakness
[QURAN:9120] is psychological and internal, related to mind and heart, and cannot be covered and concealed
[QURAN:9121] by sticking leaves over one's body. So in the context of this error, whatever it was, which
[QURAN:9122] Adam and Eve committed, coverage can only mean seeking forgiveness from Allah and
[QURAN:9123] (seeking protection from Allah). As such leaves of jannah '--4 (garden) must be understood
[QURAN:9124] metaphorically to mean seeking shelter under Allah's forgiveness and that is exactly what
[QURAN:9125] Adam did according lo the Qur'an where it is clearly mentioned that God Himself taught him
[QURAN:9126] those words which would rid him of the effects of his error and in response to those words God
[QURAN:9127] turned to him with mercy and forgiveness.

[QURAN:12954] ,:, 88. And We spoke to Moses and his brother, saying, 'Build houses for your people in the city
[QURAN:12955] and make your houses facing in the same direction, and observe Prayer.
[QURAN:12956] Note: The Arabic words waj'ah, huy11takum qihlatan l�;.D W.1�15) in this verse may
[QURAN:12957] mean: facing the Qiblah i.e., the point or place to which the worship is oriented or facing each
[QURAN:12958] other or facing in the same direction.
[QURAN:12959] As for the first meaning it is difficult to adopt this because there was no definite
[QURAN:12960] Qi blah prescribed for the Children of Israel before the building of the Temple of Solomon.
[QURAN:12961] Tf thc second meaning is preferred then the scenario will be that of houses built facing
[QURAN:12962] each other for the purpose of security.
[QURAN:12963] We prefer the third option, meaning: build your houses facing the same direction.
[QURAN:12964] This has the advantage of enabling all the dwellers of the houses lo worship in the same
[QURAN:12965] direction which creates a sense of unity and discipline among them.
[QURAN:12966] Immediately after this instruction the believers are admonished to observe Prayer
[QURAN:12967] which further strengthens our view. Because the Arabic word aqtmu$,)'aiata (;�11�1)
[QURAN:12968] does not merely enjoin performance of individual Prayer but emphasises the performance of
[QURAN:12969] Prayer in congregation.

[QURAN:13258] Note: It is very important to determine to whom the pronoun 'they' refers. The only two
[QURAN:13259] persons mentioned in this verse are the Holy Prophet (may peace and blessings of Allah be
[QURAN:13260] upon him) and the Divine witness who is to follow him. As far as Moses is concerned, it is not
[QURAN:13261] he but his Book to which reference is made because Books do not believe. It leaves us with the
[QURAN:13262] only option that a body of people is implied in the verse. The pronoun refers not only lo the
[QURAN:13263] Prophet himself but also to his subordinate witness and some others.
[QURAN:13264] The above verse should be understood in the same context that not only the Prophet
[QURAN:13265] and his witness believe in the truth of the Prophet and testify lo it, but also the large number of
[QURAN:13266] their followers do the same.
[QURAN:13267] It should be remembered that sometimes great Prophets are mentioned in the singular
[QURAN:13268] as one person but they have the potential to multiply and spread out. They are referred to as
[QURAN:13269] wnmah (a...1), a large body of people in themselves. For refe,.renee see chapter 16 verse 121.
[QURAN:13270] Some have understood the pronoun 'they' (u/ii 'ika -1'.;J,i) to refer to Moses and his people.

[QURAN:13692] Note: It was a most apt and disarming retort to a people who were not interested in the charms
[QURAN:13693] of the opposite sex. Virtually women were chaste for them. It is to this that the expression

[QURAN:13695] had offered them his own daughters so that the honour of his guests could be protected al the
[QURAN:13696] cost, as ifhc were inviting them to abuse their innocence. Evidently this reply was a reflection
[QURAN:13697] of their perverted nature.

[QURAN:14237] ,:, 32. Note: The words qa//a 'na aidiyahunna (~)-di ~) 'cut their hands' can be understood to
[QURAN:14238] apply literally or metaphorically as l:la<_lrat Imam Raghib has mentioned both usages with
[QURAN:14239] reference to the use of this word in the Holy Qur'an.
[QURAN:14240] Here the literal meaning of (~)-d' ~) would be lo sever one's hand with some
[QURAN:14241] sharp instrument. This obviously is not meant by the Holy Qur'an and is inconceivable in this
[QURAN:14242] context. As an alternative, some scholars have attempted lo attribute a minimised action of
[QURAN:14243] cutting, indicating just a few minor cuts, but the Arabic usage docs not approve of it because
[QURAN:14244] the force and the intensity of the root meaning in the measure of(~) does not permit this
[QURAN:14245] mild connotation. The only choice therefore is between the literal and metaphorical meaning
[QURAN:14246] and we believe that this expression in the given context can only be rightly understood
[QURAN:14247] metaphorically, meaning that they accepted defeat by considering him inaccessible and beyond
[QURAN:14248] the reach of their hands.

[QURAN:15275] ,:, 10. Note: The Quranic expression/araddii aidiyahwn f7 afwiihihim (~1,_;1 ~~~( 13;;;)
[QURAN:15276] (they turned their hands to their mouths) paints a picture of somebody putting his hand to his
[QURAN:15277] mouth indicating blockade. Before explaining this special expression one has also to determine
[QURAN:15278] as to who is referred to in this verse. Evidently this act is attributed to non-believers; so it has
[QURAN:15279] two possibilities of interpretation. It can be translated as: they, the non-believers, thrust their
[QURAN:15280] hands into their own mouths. This means that they refused to have any dialogue with the
[QURAN:15281] Messengers and their followers. This stage is reached when a person is ultimately nonplussed
[QURAN:15282] and is left with no arguments. So he acquires this posture of boycott, indicating that he has
[QURAN:15283] nothing more lo say.
[QURAN:15284] Tn the second reading the reference may be to the mouths of the Messengers. Tt also
[QURAN:15285] indicates the same break in dialogue but in a different way. Hence the message would be that
[QURAN:15286] the non-believers finally slop Messengers from further preaching telling them lo shut their
[QURAN:15287] mouths. This alternative is further supported by the remaining part of the verse where the non­
[QURAN:15288] believers continue to develop the theme by saying further: 'We have rejected the message with
[QURAN:15289] which you were sent and verily we are in manifold doubt regarding that lo which you call us.'

[QURAN:15953] Chapter 15 - 10 ~;
[QURAN:15954] ,:, 91. Like always We shall send down punishment upon those who become split into sects,
[QURAN:15955] ,:, 92. And who would split the Qur'an into segments.
[QURAN:15956] Note: We prefer to translate the verses (88-92) in the future tense rather than the past because
[QURAN:15957] we consider them to possess a grave warning lo Muslims. There is no wonder why the past
[QURAN:15958] tense is used to indicate future, because most of such prophecies as arc inevitably bound to be
[QURAN:15959] fulfilled are expressed in the past tense in the Holy Qur'an. The past is unchangeable.
[QURAN:15960] Prophecies in the past tense emphasise certainty. Thus the translation should run as follows:
[QURAN:15961] "And We have, indeed given thee the seven oft repeated verses and the great
[QURAN:15962] Qur'an. Do not stretch your eyes with greed towards the transient pleasure We have
[QURAN:15963] bestowed upon various groups among them, and grieve not over them; and lower your
[QURAN:15964] wing of mercy for the believers. And say, I am a plain Warner indeed. Like always, We
[QURAN:15965] shall send down punishment upon those who become split into sects, and who would split
[QURAN:15966] the Qur'iin into segments."
[QURAN:15967] This translation becomes evidently more appropriate when we bring into view the
[QURAN:15968] context of these verses and discover that the preceding verses begin with a dramatic introduction
[QURAN:15969] of the Holy Qur'an as a great Book. So all those who, despite claiming subservience lo the
[QURAN:15970] Qur'an, disregard its most central message of unity, and get split into sects and to prove their
[QURAN:15971] own interpretation to be right end up by practically splitting the Qur'an into segments: each
[QURAN:15972] group sticking to some verses interpreting them to their own advantage as against others who
[QURAN:15973] stick to some other verses interpreting them to their own advantage. This split is described to
[QURAN:15974] be so sharp and final that there is left no possibility of compromise between different warring
[QURAN:15975] factions. This causes people of the same wnmah to split into sects and in the same process to
[QURAN:15976] divide the Qur'an into segments.

[QURAN:15978] (Seedetailsoftransliterationon page 'p').

[QURAN:16100] ,:, 16. And He has placed in the earth firm mountains to sustain you, and rivers and paths so that
[QURAN:16101] you keep to the right path.
[QURAN:16102] Note: Many scholars have translated the phrase an tamTda hikum (;i, ~"'')as 'quake' which
[QURAN:16103] if accepted would mean that God is counting His bounties upon mankind by reminding them
[QURAN:16104] that He has created mountains to cause great earthquakes spelling destructions far and wide.
[QURAN:16105] Unfortunately, it has been ignored that the word tamtda (~) is derived from miida (,~)
[QURAN:16106] which means to provide food. The word mii"idah (•,.;~) used in the Holy Qur'an is from the
[QURAN:16107] same infinitive. With this meaning in view the entire understanding of this verse will be
[QURAN:16108] transformed. It will remind mankind that God has created mountains which are essential for
[QURAN:16109] providing food to all living beings. The water is constantly lifted from lakes, seas and oceans by
[QURAN:16110] evaporation carried by higher altitude to get condensed into thicker particles. The existence of
[QURAN:16111] mountains is essential for turning the vapour into water again, thus producing wide-spread rains
[QURAN:16112] which are channelled back to earth to create immense food chains. This translation is the only
[QURAN:16113] one which fits into the context and is in perfect agreement with the remaining part of the verse.
[QURAN:16114] The correct meaning, therefore, would be: 'He has entrenched mountains over the earth so
[QURAN:16115] that they may provide you with food, and rivers and tracks so that you may be guided.'
[QURAN:16116] The relation of waler and food is obvious. In the history of civilisation it was rivers
[QURAN:16117] which played the most important role in making the mountainous terrains possible and paths
[QURAN:16118] were carved along the courses of rivers.

[QURAN:16853] ,:, 125. The punishment for profaning the Sabbath was imposed upon those who differed
[QURAN:16854] regarding him, Abraham and his religion, and your Lord will surely judge between them on
[QURAN:16855] the Day of Resurrection about that in which they differed.
[QURAN:16856] Note: The context is clear. Nothing but Abraham and his unshakable devotion and dedication
[QURAN:16857] to the Oneness of God is being discussed. Hence the reference has to be lo Abraham and the

[QURAN:16860] their practices they might have attributed them also lo Abraham. The Sabbath in this context
[QURAN:16861] appears to be not only a day of rest but also a day of purification and penance.

[QURAN:17588] AL-KAHF
[QURAN:17589] (Revealed hefi,re l fiirah)
[QURAN:17590] 1. In the name of Allah, the
[QURAN:17591] Gracious, the Merciful.
[QURAN:17592] ,:,2. All praise belongs to Allah Who
[QURAN:17593] has sent down the Book to His
[QURAN:17594] servant and has not put therein any
[QURAN:17595] crookedness.
[QURAN:17596] 3. He has made it a guardian, that it
[QURAN:17597] may give warning of a grievous
[QURAN:17598] chastisement from Him, and that it
[QURAN:17599] may give the believers who do
[QURAN:17600] good deeds the glad tidings that
[QURAN:17601] they shall have a good reward,
[QURAN:17602] 4. Wherein they shall abide for
[QURAN:17603] ever;
[QURAN:17604] 5. And that it may warn those who
[QURAN:17605] say, 'Allah has taken unto Himself
[QURAN:17606] a son.'
[QURAN:17607] 6. No knowledge have they thereof,
[QURAN:17608] nor had their fathers. Grievous is the

[QURAN:17615] ,:,2. All praise belongs to Allah Who has sent down the Book to His servant and He employed
[QURAN:17616] no crookedness in his or in its making.
[QURAN:17617] Note: The pronoun hu (•) in lahu (!..J) equally applies lo the servant of Allah-the recipient of
[QURAN:17618] the Book and the Book itself. Hence it cannot be translated into English using a pronoun
[QURAN:17619] simultaneously applicable to both. Ifone translates this as 'God has not placed any crookedness
[QURAN:17620] in it,' it will exclude the Holy Prophet (may peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) from
[QURAN:17621] this promise of purity. If one translates it as, 'He has not placed any crookedness in him,' then
[QURAN:17622] the Book is left out of this sanctity. To resolve this problem we have translated the verse in a
[QURAN:17623] different style keeping absolutely loyal to the spirit rather than overemphasising the letter.

[QURAN:19849] Chapter 21 - r1 ,¼3~1
[QURAN:19850] ,:, 64. He replied, 'Aye, somebody has surely done this. Here is the chief suspect. Ask them if
[QURAN:19851] they arc capable of speaking.'
[QURAN:19852] Note: Some translators avoid literal translation of this verse fearing that this would present
[QURAN:19853] Abraham as a liar. Obviously it was not the big idols who had smashed the smaller ones but it
[QURAN:19854] was Abraham himself who had done it. Therefore attributing the statement to Abraham that
[QURAN:19855] 'here is their chief/ would be tantamount to attributing an obvious lie to Abraham. It should
[QURAN:19856] be noted, however, that it was not a misstatement but a powerful style of argument. Sometimes
[QURAN:19857] a thing is too obvious for anybody to believe and a statement to that effect is never understood
[QURAN:19858] as a wilful attempt to mislead others but considered an exposition of the inherent absurdity of
[QURAN:19859] a situation. We believe that Abraham did make that statement without the slightest intention of
[QURAN:19860] misleading them but only by way of a powerful argument against the falsity of their belief.
[QURAN:19861] This is exactly how they took it. Having heard Abraham, none of them retorted by calling him
[QURAN:19862] a liar. But according to the Holy Qur'an they were introspectively forced to realise the folly of
[QURAN:19863] their belief. This is made clear in the following verses (see verses 65 lo 68). Again, it should
[QURAN:19864] be remembered that before this incident Abraham himself had mentioned in public his resolve
[QURAN:19865] to smash their idols (see verse 58).

[QURAN:23205] ,:,39. He said, 'O nobles, which of you will bring me her throne before they come lo me
[QURAN:23206] offering submission?'
[QURAN:23207] Note: From the following verses, it becomes clear that Solomon docs not refer to her throne
[QURAN:23208] itself. He either means a throne very similar lo hers should be manufactured or that a very
[QURAN:23209] faithful replica of her throne should be brought to him. Before her intended visit to the court
[QURAN:23210] of Solomon, she is given the surprise of finding a throne very similar to her own but in the
[QURAN:23211] possession of Solomon. From the verses which follow, the scenario that emerges clearly
[QURAN:23212] indicates that each of the nobles of his court wanted the task to be assigned to him, each
[QURAN:23213] boasting to perform the task quicker and better than his rivals. Ultimately, when the replica
[QURAN:23214] was first presented to him, he praised God for it and issued instructions to modify it further so
[QURAN:23215] that it might resemble the Queen of Saba's throne ever more closely and so deflate her pride
[QURAN:23216] in possessing a unique throne. The expression nakkiru /aha 'arshaha( •_,jj.< ·-,i ,;;43) clearly
[QURAN:23217] supports this meaning and implies that if she saw a throne very similar to her own, she would
[QURAN:23218] naturally infer that her own throne was not as unique and special as she thought it was. So the
[QURAN:23219] meaning of nakkin, (.;;43) in this context would make her throne seem common-looking.
[QURAN:23220] When she actually saw the throne built by Solomon's craftsmen, her response was not that of
[QURAN:23221] a Queen who only recently had her own throne stolen, nor that of a Queen who could not
[QURAN:23222] recognise her own throne because the craftsmen had worked on itto render it unrecognisable.

[QURAN:24874] ,:, 31. So set your face towards religion ever inclined to truth-and follow the nature of Allah
[QURAN:24875] after which He fashioned all mankind. There is no altering the creation of Allah. That
[QURAN:24876] indeed is the religion which is firmly upright and supports others to be upright.
[QURAN:24877] Note: Here the nature of Allah refers to His attributes. In this context it means that man has
[QURAN:24878] been made capable of imitating the attributes of Allah. That is the only way by which man can
[QURAN:24879] spiritually evolve. Evidently other animals cannot share this unique distinction of man. In
[QURAN:24880] other words, nearness to Allah can only be achieved if His excellent attributes arc acquired.
[QURAN:24881] However it should be remembered that Allah is infinite while man is finite. As such man can
[QURAN:24882] only imitate Him within the scope of his human limitations.

[QURAN:27600] there is many a doer of good and many a one who is manifestly cruel to himself.
[QURAN:27601] Note: The word :,iilim (;,iS;) ( cruel) or ;;;ulm (,.;.;;) ( cruelty) is not always used as condemnation
[QURAN:27602] without exception in the Holy Qur'an . When used in this sense it covers all categories of
[QURAN:27603] deviation from the right path. Yet, there are some exceptions where it is used to signify
[QURAN:27604] praiseworthiness.
[QURAN:27605] In 35 :33 (Fa\ir), it is evident that God has included amongst His chosen servants, such people
[QURAN:27606] as arc zii/imu/ /inafs'ihf (,-.,.1i.J;,J'J;) who treat themselves cruelly as they strive in the path of
[QURAN:27607] Allah. In the same category those belonging to the comparatively higher order are mentioned
[QURAN:27608] as muqtayid (~) and sabiq bilkhairat (-=,~i;J,c..o). (Fa(ir Ch:35 Verse 33)
[QURAN:27609] Similarly, to bring oneself to do good deeds req~i;es a measure of harshness and cruelty to
[QURAN:27610] oneself during early stages of spiritual struggle. Those who do it for the sake of God arc
[QURAN:27611] evidently praiseworthy, yet they are spoken of as ;;;alimul /inaf,ihf (,-.,.1i.j;,J'J;) ( cruel to himself).

[QURAN:30428] Note: The word as-sci'ah (:u:c.£.J!) literally translated as 'the Hour' should be understood in the
[QURAN:30429] light of the same expression used in (54:2) Surah Al-Qama~ There the revolutionary changes
[QURAN:30430] which were destined lo be brought about by the advent of the Holy Prophet Muhammad (may
[QURAN:30431] peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) are referred to as as-sii 'ah (:u:c.wi). And the splitting
[QURAN:30432] of the moon is presented as evidence in favour of the spiritual revolution which was about to
[QURAN:30433] take place. The connotation of this terrn as applied to Jesus in the verse under study should be
[QURAN:30434] understood on the same lines. Hence 'the Hour' refers lo the advent of Jesus in the latter days
[QURAN:30435] and the spiritual revolution attendant upon it.

[QURAN:36098] Note: The word thiyabiika (~lg) may mean heart but only ifit were taken as a figure of
[QURAN:36099] speech. But the problem is that the word thiyiih (--,, lg) literally means clothes or garments. So
[QURAN:36100] if one treats it as a figure of speech then the heart is not the only possible interpretation. More
[QURAN:36101] likely perhaps thiyahiika (.fl.;lg) in this context could refer to the companions of the Holy
[QURAN:36102] Prophet (may peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and the others close to him. Hence
[QURAN:36103] the suggested alternative translation is literal providing the reader a wider choice of
[QURAN:36104] interpretation.

[QURAN:38460] SOME ARABIC WORDS EXPLAINED
[QURAN:38461] Abii lahab: His real name was 'Abdul-'Uzza and he was an uncle of the Holy Prophet'".
[QURAN:38462] Al-Jiiaz: is one of those mountains which divide Armenia on the south from
[QURAN:38463] Mesopotamia and that part of Assyria which is inhabited by the Curds, from
[QURAN:38464] whom the mountain took the name of Cardu or Gardu but the Greeks turned
[QURAN:38465] it into Gordyaei. The remains of the ark were to be seen on the Gordyaen
[QURAN:38466] mountains, and Emperor Heraclius is said to have gone from the town of
[QURAN:38467] Thamanin up to the mountain al-Judi and saw the place of the ark. There
[QURAN:38468] was also formerly a famous monastery on one of these mountains called the
[QURAN:38469] monastery of the ark.
[QURAN:38470] Allah: The proper name of God.
[QURAN:38471] As-Sa/ii wal-Marwah: Two hills near the Ka 'bah in Mecca which Arabian history and
[QURAN:38472] the traditions oflslam connect with the story of Hagar and Ishmael. Abraham
[QURAN:38473] left them in the wilderness near these hills. They stand as a monument to
[QURAN:38474] Hagar's travail when she ran between them seven times in search of water for
[QURAN:38475] Ishmael, and seven circuits between these hills constitute one of the rites of
[QURAN:38476] the Pilgrimage.
[QURAN:38477] 'Arafat: The name given to a plain or valley near Mecca where pilgrims halt in the
[QURAN:38478] latter portion of the ninth day of Dhu'l-l:lijjah. It is nine miles from Mecca
[QURAN:38479] and the halt of the pilgrims at this place forms one of the principal ceremonies
[QURAN:38480] of the Pilgrimage.
[QURAN:38481] Badr: Literally meaning 'full moon,' is the name of a place on the route between
[QURAN:38482] Mecca and Medina. Here the first regular battle took place between Muslims
[QURAN:38483] and the Quraish of Mecca in which the Quraishite power received a severe
[QURAN:38484] shaking.

[QURAN:38487] dedicated to some god and its milk was not used, nor its back.

[QURAN:38489] Becca: is the name given to the valley of Mecca. The word is also considered by
[QURAN:38490] some to be the same as Mecca, its mfm having been changed into bii.

[QURAN:38494] famous dream.

[QURAN:38508] SOME ARABIC WORDS EXPLAINED
[QURAN:38509] Jdrzs: Enoch of the Bible.
[QURAN:38510] Jiilut: In the Bible the parallel name is Goliath (I Sam. 17: 4) which means, running,
[QURAN:38511] ravaging and destroying spirits or 'a leader' or 'a giant'.
[QURAN:38512] Jinn: This word has been applied in the Qur'an to the following:
[QURAN:38513] (a)Evil spirits which inspire evil thoughts in the minds of men. They are the
[QURAN:38514] agents of Satan;
[QURAN:38515] (b) Some imaginary beings whom the infidels worshipped but who existed
[QURAN:38516] nowhere in the world;
[QURAN:38517] (c) The inhabitants of northern hilly tracts of Europe, of white and red colour,
[QURAN:38518] whom other peoples looked upon as beings separate from other human beings
[QURAN:38519] and who lived detached from the civilized peoples of Asia but who were
[QURAN:38520] destined to make great material progress in the latter days and to lead a great
[QURAN:38521] revolt against religion;
[QURAN:38522] (d) Peoples belonging to alien religions and nationalities; and
[QURAN:38523] (c) Wild and savage peoples who in pre-historic times, before man had
[QURAN:38524] developed enough morally to be given a revealed code oflaws, lived in caves
[QURAN:38525] and hollows of the earth and were subject to no rules of conduct.
[QURAN:38526] Ka 'bah: The sacred House at Mecca to which Muslims turn their faces while praying.
[QURAN:38527] Mann: The root meaning of this word is: (I) a favour; (2) anything obtained without
[QURAN:38528] trouble or difficulty; (3) honey-dew.
[QURAN:38529] Mash 'aru/-ljariim: is the name given to a small hill in Muzdalifah which lies between
[QURAN:38530] Mecca and 'Arafat. It is about six miles from Mecca. Herc the pilgrims stop
[QURAN:38531] for the night after their return from 'Arafat on the evening of the ninth day of
[QURAN:38532] the month of J:[ajj.
[QURAN:38533] Qiblah: Literally meaning direction to which a person turns while praying, refers to
[QURAN:38534] the Ka'bah at Mecca.
[QURAN:38535] Quraish: A famous tribe of Mecca to which the Holy Prophet'" belonged.
[QURAN:38536] Rii 'inii: The word means, 'look to us', but with a little change of the accent the word
[QURAN:38537] means, a foolish or conceited person.
[QURAN:38538] Sii 'ibah: A she-camel set free by the Arabs to go wherever she pleased, generally as
[QURAN:38539] an offering to the gods. Often a she-camel having given birth to ten female
[QURAN:38540] young ones was let loose to pasture where she would, and she was not ridden
[QURAN:38541] nor was her milk drunk except by her young.
[QURAN:38542] Salwii: A whitish bird resembling a quail found in some parts of Arabia and the
[QURAN:38543] neighbouring countries. The root meaning of this word is: (I) whatever
[QURAN:38544] renders a person contented and happy; (2) honey.
[QURAN:38545] Shahru Ramarjiin: The Islamic month of fasting.
[QURAN:38546] Tiihit: In the Bible the parallel name is Saul (I Sam. 10: 23).
[QURAN:38547] Tuwii: The name of the valley where the first manifestation of God to Moses took place.
[QURAN:38548] 'Umrah: Lesser Pilgrimage in which some of the rites of the Pilgrimage arc left out.
[QURAN:38549] Un{'.urna: The word means, 'have regard for us'.
[QURAN:38550] Wiidiun-Naml: The name ofa valley which is situated between Jibrun and 'Asqalan,
[QURAN:38551] and N amlah is the name of a tribe.
[QURAN:38552] Wai)zlah: A she-camel that was let loose by the Arabs in the name of a god after she
[QURAN:38553] had given birth to seven female ones consecutively. If, at the seventh birth,
[QURAN:38554] she bore a pair, male and female, these were also let loose.
